title: Enthalpy change for dissolution of CuCl

content.description:
The particle diagram shown above represents the dissolution of <math alttext="C u C l solid" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> assuming an equilibrium concentration for <math alttext="C u with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions of about <math alttext="4 times 10 to the negative 4 power molar" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in a saturated solution at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The equilibrium being represented is shown in the following chemical equation.

<math alttext="Cu C l solid is in equilibrium with C u with a positive 1 charge aqueous plus C l with a negative 1 charge aqueous " overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuCl</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: Which of the following best explains whether or not the particle diagram can predict the relative value of the enthalpy change for the dissolution of <math alttext="C u C l solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: The value of the enthalpy change for the dissolution of <math alttext="C u C l solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> cannot be predicted from the particle diagram because it fails to illustrate the amount of energy required to overcome the forces between solute particles and between solvent particles.

The value of the enthalpy change for the dissolution of <math alttext="C u C l solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> cannot be predicted from the particle diagram because it fails to illustrate the amount of energy released when the water molecules form hydrogen bonds with <math alttext="C l with a negative 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions.

The value of the enthalpy change for the dissolution of <math alttext="C u C l solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is positive (endothermic) because energy is released to overcome the forces between solute particles, as shown in the particle diagram.

The value of the enthalpy change for the dissolution of <math alttext="C u C l solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is negative (exothermic) because energy is required when the bonds between the ions are broken, as shown in the particle diagram.

content.answer: The value of the enthalpy change for the dissolution of <math alttext="C u C l solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> cannot be predicted from the particle diagram because it fails to illustrate the amount of energy required to overcome the forces between solute particles and between solvent particles.

skill.text: 4.D: Explain the degree to which a model or representation describes the connection between particulate-level properties and macroscopic properties.
